shortLinksItems.dek: Holiday planning starts with a bit of inspiration, beyond the well-trodden territory of tropical beaches and European cities. Looking for a different kind of vacation in 2015? It’s the year to hike the Southern Alps of New Zealand, head to the Bahamas, or visit Cuba for the first time. Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.

items.title: Cartagena, Colombia
items.caption: Cartagena, a perfectly preserved 17th-century port city on the Caribbean coast of Colombia, has had a rough ride over the centuries. From pirates to prostitutes (aren't they synonymous?) the city has weathered its fair share of drama—thanks to everything from Gabriel García Márquez's remarkable novels of "magical realism" to the less-than-palatable shenanigans of U.S. Secret Service agents in 2012. Tips: Don't take a carriage ride through town, and avoid very late night stumbles through San Diego and Centro. Do, however, explore the up-and-coming Getsemaní neighborhood for its raucous Wednesday-night parties and interesting graffiti art. The chic Viceroy hotel group may deliver a new bolt-hole soon in a converted convent.*—David Jefferys*

items.title: Santa Teresa, Costa Rica
items.caption: New direct flights into Liberia, in Guanacaste (like JetBlue’s route from Boston), slash the drive time to this resort town, which has attracted the likes of Gisele Bündchen and Tom Brady. In Playa Hermosa, Koji’s serves the best sushi and Japanese food in Costa Rica at wooden tables under strings of fairy lights. The ginger pork and super-fresh sushi rolls are a light alterna- tive to plantains and gallo pinto in the heat *(506-2640- 0815; entrées from $20).*—Alice Newell-Hanson*

items.title: Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
items.caption: The furnaces are long gone, but this city’s on fire. Pittsburgh reinvigorates my love of art every time I visit. The Carnegie Museum of Art, The Warhol, Mattress Factory, and Wood Street Galleries have been on a curatorial tear in recent years. The restaurant scene is also alight, led by Cure and Bar Marco, but hit the old school Primanti Brothers for the best sandwich of your life.*—Brent Burket*

items.title: Mexico City, Mexico
items.caption: Mexico City has had a hard time divesting itself of a reputation for being crime-ridden, traffic congested, and highly polluted. And though traffic and air quality are ongoing problems, this sprawling metropolis of over 20 million inhabitants has successfully transformed itself into a vibrant and relatively safe place to visit with a great restaurant scene, world-class museums, and a sophistication befitting its position as one of the world's top cities. *—Stephen Orr*

items.title: Rwanda
items.caption: I'm very interested in going to Rwanda. The horrific inter-tribal genocide of the 1990s is a thing of the past but still remains the event most identified with this country in the mind of Americans. Instead, it should be more known for its beautiful high-altitude forests, its lakes, and Kigali, its capital city. Paul Kagame, Rwanda's highly effective if controversially autocratic president, is credited with putting the country's economy on the rise. And most of all, I want to see the mountain gorillas in their home in the Virunga Mountains.*—SO*

items.title: Myanmar
items.caption: Myanmar is like Southeast Asia's last frontier, where almost everything still feels undiscovered and off the beaten path after decades of military rule. But go now—luxury hotels are springing up in Yangon (the capital), and it probably won't be long before tourist hordes descend on temple-studded Bagan, making it feel (unfortunately) like another Angkor Wat in terms of the insane crowds. *—John Wogan*

items.title: Nassau, The Bahamas
items.caption: The islands’ busiest airport, Lynden Pindling International, in Nassau, completed a $410 million expansion last year, and the 988-acre Baha Mar resort opens on Nassau’s Cable Beach in 2015, just in time for spring break. Of the four hotels within the complex, we’re most excited about the Rosewood *(1 Baha Mar Blvd.; 242-677- 9750; bahamar.com; doubles from $800)*. Play croquet on is U.S.– regulation lawns, then head to the hotel’s Riva Bar for a Dark ’n’ Stormy made with Bahamian rum. *—ANH*

items.title: Belgrade, Serbia
items.caption: The former capital of Yugoslavia has a tough reputation that belies a vibrant culture that seems both ancient and modern. Visit the Palace of Serbia and the Hotel Jugoslavija (pristine examples of mid-century modernism), check out the Nikola Tesla Museum, walk the old-town neighborhood of Skadarlija, or explore St. Sava—the world’s largest Orthodox church. The nightlife scene is also one of Europe’s most underrated. *—Calder Quinn*

items.title: Helsinki
items.caption: Helsinki always gets outshined by Scandinavian siblings Stockholm and Copenhagen, but the Finnish capital is an underrated (and more reasonably priced) joy. From the gorgeous Helsinki Cathedral (pictured) to the Rock Church and the Seurasaari Open-Air Museum, there's no shortage of striking design. Start the day with Karelian rye pastries stuffed with hearty rice pudding and end it with long drink, a gin-and-grapefruit-soda cocktail invented specifically for the 1952 Summer Olympics and so beloved by locals that it stayed well past its temporary run.*—Lilit Marcus*

items.title: Berlin
items.caption: The Berlin Wall came down 25 years ago, but you can still see hints of the former East and West cities as you walk through the German capital. There are tasteful, well-thought-out museums about the Stasi, the Holocaust, and the city itself, but there's also plenty of light amid the darkness. By day, have coffee and cake in a cool, design-focused coffee shop like [Westberlin](http://www.westberlin-bar-shop.de/); by night,  check out a band or DJ set at iconic live music venue [Lido](http://www.lido-berlin.de/) and dance til the wee hours at [Berghain](http://www.berghain.de/), which is so cutting-edge that there are no phones allowed.*—LM*

items.title: Cape Town
items.caption: Industry insiders are abuzz about this vibrant South African city, where striking mountainous scenery, gorgeous beaches, and the chance to get up close to amazing marine and wildlife now competes for travelers’ attention with an elevated shopping, dining, and nightlife scene. The V&A Waterfront is a must for exploring and taking a boat ride to visit Robben Island’s rich history; adventurers shouldn’t miss taking a cable car ride up the spectacular Table Mountain or driving a rented sidecar—our favorite way to view Cape Town.

items.title: Houston
items.caption: Don't get us wrong: Traveler enjoys a [long weekend in Austin](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-23/perfect-summer-getaway-austin) as much as the next guy. But if Austin is the hipster-cool college party of Texas, Houston is the adult dinner party where we prefer to be wined and dined. [Is Houston the new "it" city?](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-11/is-houston-the-new-it-city), we asked in September—it seems that way, with plenty of hip places to eat, stay, and play in the bustling Texas city. *—Katherine Shilcutt*

items.title: Cuba
items.caption: Under Obama, traveling to Cuba legally from the U.S. has gotten much easier—[whether on a group tour](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-20/how-to-travel-to-cuba) or a"[people-to-people" trip](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-21/why-npr-s-david-greene-thinks-all-americans-should-visit-cuba-now). Beyond the embargo, the [art scene](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-20/discovering-cuban-culture) in Cuba thrives—it's full of exciting and experimental work, and much of it is largely affordable. You can even bring artwork back with you to the States without much hassle. *—Liz Dosta*

items.title: Milford Sound, New Zealand
items.caption: Thirteen years and six films later, Peter Jackson’s re-imagining of Tolkien’s tomes is complete. (We think.) As the stand-in for Middle-earth, New Zealand may never be the same again—but now that filming is over, the hobbit-seeking hordes might go elsewhere. Now’s the time to plan a trip to the Milford Sound area in the South Island, outside adventure travel capital Queenstown. Go "tramping" (hiking) along mountain faces, through dense, electric green forests, and past waterfalls (the Routeburn Track is highly recommended)—many of these locations appeared in the *Lord of the Rings* films. (Milford Sound, for example, stood in for Fangorn Forest.) *—Laura Dannen Redman*

items.title: Guangzhou, China
items.caption: China Southern Airlines has launched direct flights between JFK and the trading port of Guangzhou—a blessing for business travelers. Plus, Guangzhou’s arts scene is growing almost as quickly as its economy. Check out the Rem Koolhaas–designed Times Museum, then fill up on dim sum in the buzzy Taojin Lu neighborhood. *—Alice Newell-Hanson*

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: Top 15 Places to Go in 2015: Cuba, Helsinki, Cape Town
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.

shortLinksItems.hed: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.
shortLinksItems.dek: The website [Sightsmap](http://www.sightsmap.com/) is a heat map for people who love travel and photography. It uses data from [Google Maps’ Panoramio photo uploader tool] (http://www.panoramio.com) to find out where travelers are taking the most pictures. Here’s what we learned about the most photographed spots in the United States—some of the findings may surprise you.

items.title: [10. Los Angeles, CA](http://www.sightsmap.com/los-angeles)
items.caption: Although Los Angeles may not be the most popular photo site with Panoramio users, there’s one place where it reigns supreme: Instagram. The photo-sharing service recently revealed its list of the [most ‘grammed spots of 2014] (http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-12-04/the-10-most-instagrammed-spots-of-2014), and several SoCal destinations—including Disneyland and Dodger Stadium—made the list. Meanwhile, the Panoramio list favors performing arts venues and sports stadiums, with the Staples Center, Ahmanson Theatre, and Dorothy Chandler Pavilion all getting high marks.

items.title: [9. Walt Disney World, FL](http://sightsmap.com/walt-disney-world)
items.caption: The [Walt Disney World](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-05-14/adult-disney-world-travel-guide-hotels-restaurants-activities) complex in Florida technically has its own town, Lake Buena Vista. People come from all over the world to visit the amusement park and resorts, and they take plenty of pictures while they’re there. Unsurprisingly, Cinderella's Castle (pictured) was the most popular spot in the Magic Kingdom. But many of the most photographed spots are in Epcot, including Norway (no. 4), Japan (no. 3), and the Mexico Pavilion (no. 9). And the iconic Epcot ball is #1.

items.title: [8. Key West, FL](http://sightsmap.com/key-west)
items.caption: As the southernmost point in the continental United States, Key West has drawn visitors as diverse as Ernest Hemingway and the cast of MTV's *The Real World.* Unsurprisingly, its most photographed spots include the Southernmost House, Hemingway’s former home (and its polydactyl cats), and other watery locales like the Shipwreck and Maritime Museums.

items.title: [7. Boston, MA](http://sightsmap.com/boston)
items.caption: Thanks to the Bay State’s key role in the founding of America, [Boston](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-12-12/what-not-to-do-in-boston) has plenty of historic attractions on offer. The city’s most photographed list is a mix of the classic and the modern, including skyscrapers like the John Hancock Tower alongside the Ether Monument (also known as the Good Samaritan), the Massachusetts State House, and the site of the Boston Massacre.

items.title: [6. Las Vegas Strip, NV](http://sightsmap.com/las-vegas-strip)
items.caption: While [Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-12-18/things-to-do-in-las-vegas-weekend-guide) is one of the most popular tourist spots in America, it’s only one part of Las Vegas that’s getting love on Panoramio: the Strip, which is where many tourists spend the majority of their visits. Unsurprisingly, that means that many of the most photographed spots are casinos, including Bally's, Caesar's Palace, and the Venetian. The most popular non-Strip spot in Sin City is "Vegas Vic," the famous neon cowboy.

items.title: [5. Washington, D.C.](http://sightsmap.com/washington-dc)
items.caption: As the nation’s capital, [Washington, D.C.](http://www.cntraveler.com/destinations/washington-dc) is heavy with history. And many of its most photographed spots are places named for some of our past leaders, including the Jefferson Memorial, the Lincoln Memorial, and the Washington Monument. But some other interesting spots make the cut, including Blair House (where many guests of the White House stay during their visit) and President’s Park (better known as the White House lawn).

items.title: [4. San Francisco, CA](http://sightsmap.com/san-francisco)
items.caption: San Francisco is the 20th best city in the world, [as voted by Condé Nast Traveler readers.] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/6). And while destinations like Coit Tower, the Golden Gate Bridge, Fisherman’s Wharf, and Alcatraz all appear on the most photographed list, the no. 1 photo tag is simply “San Francisco.” That’s right: the city itself is the star.

items.title: [3. Chicago, IL](http://sightsmap.com/chicago)
items.caption: *Condé Nast Traveler* readers love Chicago, putting it at no. 23 on our poll of the [top 25 cities in the world] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/3). The Windy City is known for its skyline, so it’s no surprise that some of its most photographed spots are landmarks like the Ferris Wheel, the Willis Tower, the Bean, and—coming in at no. 1—the Art Institute of Chicago.

items.title: [2. Niagara Falls, NY](http://sightsmap.com/niagara-falls)
items.caption: Both the United States and Canada experienced a high volume of tourists who wanted to photograph [the gorgeous waterfalls](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-01-10/niagara-falls-frozen-ice) on both sides of the border. Here, it’s all about the vantage points: Hot spots include the Rainbow Bridge, the Observation Deck, and the Maid of the Mists boats that go through the falls.

items.title: [1. New York, NY](http://sightsmap.com/new-york-city)
items.caption: [New York City](http://www.cntraveler.com/destinations/new-york-city) is not only the most photographed city in the US, it’s the most photographed city in the entire world. Visitors to the Big Apple like to take pictures of the city’s architectural marvels, including the Empire State Building, the 9/11 Memorial, the Flatiron Building, and Grand Central Terminal. But the big winner was the [Guggenheim Museum](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/new-york/solomon-r-guggenheim-museum), whose circular shape and iconic works of art prove an irresistible combination.

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: New York, Chicago, San Francisco: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Here’s what we learned about the most photographed spots in the United States—some of the findings may surprise you.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.

fields.caption:
The observation deck at One World Trade Center won't be open until spring 2015 at the earliest, but, when it does, it'll let visitors look out over New York City from approximately 1,250 feet above. Plans for restaurants, a multimedia gallery, and another ultra-fast elevator ride are also in the works.




 




**More on Incredible Views:**




[Amazing Observatories Around the World Perfect for Stargazing](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/amazing-observatories-you-can-visit_slideshow_item0_1)




[Room With a View](http://www.cntraveler.com/room-with-a-view/photos-room-with-a-view)




[Hotel Rooftops, Balconies and Terraces Worth the Price of the Room](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/best-hotel-rooftops-balconies-and-terraces)
fields.title: One World Observatory

fields.name: Lilit Marcus
fields.shortBio: Lilit Marcus is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor.
fields.bio: Lilit Marcus is a Brooklyn-based journalist and *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor. Her first book, *Save the Assistants: A Guide for Surviving and Thriving in the Workplace,* was published by Hyperion. Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

shortLinksItems.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers pick their favorite destination spas in the world.

items.title: [Red Mountain Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/bermuda/red-mountain-resort-spa-st-george-st-george-utah)
items.caption:
Our readers rave about the location of this resort, calling it "heaven on Earth, close to national park day excursions." They also appreciated the activities: The resort offers daily guided hikes through nearby Snow Canyon State Park, fitness and health classes, and plenty of ways to be pampered at the spa. "Fabulous for all sorts of activities at any level," said one reader, "rest and relaxation by the pool or in a secluded hammock."







**Overall Score: 80.8**


See full rating information for **[Red Mountain Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/bermuda/red-mountain-resort-spa-st-george-st-george-utah)**.

items.title: [Canyon Ranch, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-tucson-tucson-arizona)
items.caption:
This is one of two Canyon Ranch resorts to make our readers' Top Ten list. One fan raved about the experience here, calling it "the ultimate in a vacation destination: diverse choices of activities, healthy, delicious, clean food, all the pampering one might desire, workshops on a variety of topics, and most importantly, a dedicated staff." Of course, all that comes with the beautiful backdrop of the Sonoran desert and the Santa Catalina Mountains. Said one happy guest: "No matter what state you arrive in, you'll leave feeling fantastic."




**Overall Score: 87.3**


See full rating information for **[Canyon Ranch, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-tucson-tucson-arizona)**.

items.title: [Canyon Ranch, Lenox](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-lenox-lenox-massachusetts)
items.caption:
This wellness resort in the Berkshires is "R&R for the soul," a reader raves. The architectural focal point is Bellefontaine Mansion, an 1897 Gilded Age house, modeled after the Petit Trianon in Versailles, that used to be a Jesuit seminary. Rooms are decorated in warm neutral tones and have Italian bed linens and granite and cherrywood bathrooms. Staff "set the bar high—and I mean high—for all spa- and wellness-focused vacations," according to another reader. The 100,000-square-foot spa has saunas, cold-dip pools, and inhalation rooms.




**Overall Score: 89.7**


See full rating information for **[Canyon Ranch, Lenox](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-lenox-lenox-massachusetts)**.

items.title: [Lodge at Woodloch](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/lodge-at-woodloch-hawley-hawley-pennsylvania)
items.caption: Ninety miles from New York City, this 2006 property with more than 150 wooded acres and a private lake in northeast Pennsylvania is “a quiet and serene resort, the perfect weekend getaway.” Excursions include fly-fishing and trail biking trips, though some prefer to stay on-site for a river stone massage at the spa. All guest rooms have private verandas and oversize marble bathrooms. Guests enter under a porte cochere into the plant-filled Garden Hall, which has a 14-foot glass cupola and a balcony looking onto the lake. Tree restaurant’s chef uses fresh, local ingredients, including those from the resort’s farm-to-table garden, to flavor dishes such as marinated lamb loin with mushroom risotto, haricots verts, and balsamic reduction. The 40,000-square-foot spa has 27 treatment rooms.

items.title: [Miraval, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/miraval-tucson-tucson-arizona)
items.caption:
Guests of this mind-body-spirit resort, near the Santa Catalina Mountains in the High Sonoran Desert, report having "life-changing, transformative stays." Villas have earth tones and are made from sustainable materials, while the grounds are "spectacular yet intimate." All meals, snacks, and non-alcoholic beverages are included and "are so inspired and flavorful, it’s hard to believe they’re so healthy." The spa’s fusion therapies combine massage, stretching, acupuncture, craniosacral therapy, and sound therapy. "Pampering, supportive staff are dedicated and love their jobs—and it shows."




**Overall Score: 92.8**


See full rating information for **[Miraval, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/miraval-tucson-tucson-arizona)**.

items.title: [Mii Amo, Sedona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/mii-amo-sedona-sedona-united-states)
items.caption:
"The staff and facilities are phenomenal" at this "outstanding, outlandish spa retreat" connected to the Enchantment Resort in a red-rock canyon sacred to Native Americans. The "truly healing environment" incorporates design elements such as adobe brick, wood, and indigenous stone, and includes a Japanese-inspired lobby courtyard. Adobe casitas sit on the banks of a stream. Guests choose from three-, four- and seven-night programs, called Journeys, that include spa treatments by "super-experienced therapists" using custom-blended oils and lotions. Mii Amo Café’s health-conscious dishes are made with seasonal produce, and the Juice Bar serves energy drinks and smoothies. "The food is like no other spa food. I mean, it’s really good."




**Overall Score: 94.1**


See full rating information for **[Mii Amo, Sedona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/mii-amo-sedona-sedona-united-states)**.

items.title: [BodyHoliday at LeSport, St. Lucia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/st-lucia/bodyholiday-at-lesport-st-lucia-st-lucia-st-lucia)
items.caption:
The only Caribbean property on our Top Destination Spas list, BodyHoliday on St. Lucia combines the best of a destination spa with an island resort—few other destination spas are able to offer Scuba classes while there’s no pressure to participate in a strict agenda of classes. “With all the activities available you can choose to be a busy or lazy as you like.” Food at the four restaurants is healthy and fresh, but not spartan and unlike many destination spas, BodyHoliday serves alcohol. “The perfect place to wind down, relax, do sports, eat healthy, and just enjoy.”




**Overall Score: 94.1**


See full rating information for **[BodyHoliday at LeSport, St. Lucia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/st-lucia/bodyholiday-at-lesport-st-lucia-st-lucia-st-lucia)**.

items.title: [Lake Austin Spa Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/lake-austin-spa-resort-austin-texas)
items.caption:
At this "amazingly secluded resort in the heart of Austin," guests can sit on their private porches overlooking either the gardens or lake (kayaks are available). After morning exercise classes, afternoon programs typically include seminars on topics like meditation and mastering your metabolism as well as cooking classes. The LakeHouse Spa staff, treatments, and facilities all received perfect scores, while many readers commented on the beauty of the landscaped grounds: "What an oasis!"

**Overall Score: **95.3
items.credit: Courtesy of Lake Austin Spa Resort

items.title: [Cal-A-Vie](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/cal-a-vie-health-spa-vista-california)
items.caption:
At this 32-room southern California resort, fitness gets a French touch, at least when it comes to the "Provencal-inspired décor and priceless antiques." A typical day at Cal-a-Vie begins with a morning hike through the canyons in the foothills above San Diego, followed by a breakfast of fresh fruits and whole grains, and then classes from ab workouts to zumba. For those so inclined, "injectables," including Botox and B12 are offered while Cal-a-Vie also has its own 18-hole golf course.




**Overall Score: 95.3**


See full rating information for **[Cal-a-Vie](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/cal-a-vie-health-spa-vista-california)**.

items.title: [Rancho La Puerta, Tecate](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/mexico/rancho-la-puerta-tecate-baja-mexico)
items.caption: **Our readers say**: “It’s a fabulous spa in a dream setting.” The 3,000-acre resort below Mount Kuchumaa, which is sacred to some Native Americans, has mountains, boulders, meadows, grasslands, woodlands, and chaparral on its grounds. The formal hiking program takes full advantage of the terrain; other options include watsu, acupuncture, hot river-stone massage, and craniosacral therapy. Built in Spanish colonial–style, red-brick casitas with tile roofs and outdoor patios are set amid extensive gardens. “This is one of my favorite places to rest, relax, and revitalize.” “Staff are helpful and friendly.” “Fantastic meals” are included in the rate—the locally sourced cuisine is primarily vegetarian. “It’s the best place to regain your health—physical and mental.” There’s a one-week

Our readers rave about the location of this resort, calling it "heaven on Earth, close to national park day excursions." They also appreciated the activities: The resort offers daily guided hikes through nearby Snow Canyon State Park, fitness and health classes, and plenty of ways to be pampered at the spa. "Fabulous for all sorts of activities at any level," said one reader, "rest and relaxation by the pool or in a secluded hammock."

fields.shortBio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.

featureContentItems.dek: Holiday planning starts with a bit of inspiration, beyond the well-trodden territory of tropical beaches and European cities. Looking for a different kind of vacation in 2015? It’s the year to hike the Southern Alps of New Zealand, head to the Bahamas, or visit Cuba for the first time. Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.

items.title: Cartagena, Colombia
items.caption: Cartagena, a perfectly preserved 17th-century port city on the Caribbean coast of Colombia, has had a rough ride over the centuries. From pirates to prostitutes (aren't they synonymous?) the city has weathered its fair share of drama—thanks to everything from Gabriel García Márquez's remarkable novels of "magical realism" to the less-than-palatable shenanigans of U.S. Secret Service agents in 2012. Tips: Don't take a carriage ride through town, and avoid very late night stumbles through San Diego and Centro. Do, however, explore the up-and-coming Getsemaní neighborhood for its raucous Wednesday-night parties and interesting graffiti art. The chic Viceroy hotel group may deliver a new bolt-hole soon in a converted convent.*—David Jefferys*

items.title: Santa Teresa, Costa Rica
items.caption: New direct flights into Liberia, in Guanacaste (like JetBlue’s route from Boston), slash the drive time to this resort town, which has attracted the likes of Gisele Bündchen and Tom Brady. In Playa Hermosa, Koji’s serves the best sushi and Japanese food in Costa Rica at wooden tables under strings of fairy lights. The ginger pork and super-fresh sushi rolls are a light alterna- tive to plantains and gallo pinto in the heat *(506-2640- 0815; entrées from $20).*—Alice Newell-Hanson*

items.title: Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
items.caption: The furnaces are long gone, but this city’s on fire. Pittsburgh reinvigorates my love of art every time I visit. The Carnegie Museum of Art, The Warhol, Mattress Factory, and Wood Street Galleries have been on a curatorial tear in recent years. The restaurant scene is also alight, led by Cure and Bar Marco, but hit the old school Primanti Brothers for the best sandwich of your life.*—Brent Burket*

items.title: Mexico City, Mexico
items.caption: Mexico City has had a hard time divesting itself of a reputation for being crime-ridden, traffic congested, and highly polluted. And though traffic and air quality are ongoing problems, this sprawling metropolis of over 20 million inhabitants has successfully transformed itself into a vibrant and relatively safe place to visit with a great restaurant scene, world-class museums, and a sophistication befitting its position as one of the world's top cities. *—Stephen Orr*

items.title: Rwanda
items.caption: I'm very interested in going to Rwanda. The horrific inter-tribal genocide of the 1990s is a thing of the past but still remains the event most identified with this country in the mind of Americans. Instead, it should be more known for its beautiful high-altitude forests, its lakes, and Kigali, its capital city. Paul Kagame, Rwanda's highly effective if controversially autocratic president, is credited with putting the country's economy on the rise. And most of all, I want to see the mountain gorillas in their home in the Virunga Mountains.*—SO*

items.title: Myanmar
items.caption: Myanmar is like Southeast Asia's last frontier, where almost everything still feels undiscovered and off the beaten path after decades of military rule. But go now—luxury hotels are springing up in Yangon (the capital), and it probably won't be long before tourist hordes descend on temple-studded Bagan, making it feel (unfortunately) like another Angkor Wat in terms of the insane crowds. *—John Wogan*

items.title: Nassau, The Bahamas
items.caption: The islands’ busiest airport, Lynden Pindling International, in Nassau, completed a $410 million expansion last year, and the 988-acre Baha Mar resort opens on Nassau’s Cable Beach in 2015, just in time for spring break. Of the four hotels within the complex, we’re most excited about the Rosewood *(1 Baha Mar Blvd.; 242-677- 9750; bahamar.com; doubles from $800)*. Play croquet on is U.S.– regulation lawns, then head to the hotel’s Riva Bar for a Dark ’n’ Stormy made with Bahamian rum. *—ANH*

items.title: Belgrade, Serbia
items.caption: The former capital of Yugoslavia has a tough reputation that belies a vibrant culture that seems both ancient and modern. Visit the Palace of Serbia and the Hotel Jugoslavija (pristine examples of mid-century modernism), check out the Nikola Tesla Museum, walk the old-town neighborhood of Skadarlija, or explore St. Sava—the world’s largest Orthodox church. The nightlife scene is also one of Europe’s most underrated. *—Calder Quinn*

items.title: Helsinki
items.caption: Helsinki always gets outshined by Scandinavian siblings Stockholm and Copenhagen, but the Finnish capital is an underrated (and more reasonably priced) joy. From the gorgeous Helsinki Cathedral (pictured) to the Rock Church and the Seurasaari Open-Air Museum, there's no shortage of striking design. Start the day with Karelian rye pastries stuffed with hearty rice pudding and end it with long drink, a gin-and-grapefruit-soda cocktail invented specifically for the 1952 Summer Olympics and so beloved by locals that it stayed well past its temporary run.*—Lilit Marcus*

items.title: Berlin
items.caption: The Berlin Wall came down 25 years ago, but you can still see hints of the former East and West cities as you walk through the German capital. There are tasteful, well-thought-out museums about the Stasi, the Holocaust, and the city itself, but there's also plenty of light amid the darkness. By day, have coffee and cake in a cool, design-focused coffee shop like [Westberlin](http://www.westberlin-bar-shop.de/); by night,  check out a band or DJ set at iconic live music venue [Lido](http://www.lido-berlin.de/) and dance til the wee hours at [Berghain](http://www.berghain.de/), which is so cutting-edge that there are no phones allowed.*—LM*

items.title: Cape Town
items.caption: Industry insiders are abuzz about this vibrant South African city, where striking mountainous scenery, gorgeous beaches, and the chance to get up close to amazing marine and wildlife now competes for travelers’ attention with an elevated shopping, dining, and nightlife scene. The V&A Waterfront is a must for exploring and taking a boat ride to visit Robben Island’s rich history; adventurers shouldn’t miss taking a cable car ride up the spectacular Table Mountain or driving a rented sidecar—our favorite way to view Cape Town.

items.title: Houston
items.caption: Don't get us wrong: Traveler enjoys a [long weekend in Austin](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-23/perfect-summer-getaway-austin) as much as the next guy. But if Austin is the hipster-cool college party of Texas, Houston is the adult dinner party where we prefer to be wined and dined. [Is Houston the new "it" city?](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-11/is-houston-the-new-it-city), we asked in September—it seems that way, with plenty of hip places to eat, stay, and play in the bustling Texas city. *—Katherine Shilcutt*

items.title: Cuba
items.caption: Under Obama, traveling to Cuba legally from the U.S. has gotten much easier—[whether on a group tour](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-20/how-to-travel-to-cuba) or a"[people-to-people" trip](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-21/why-npr-s-david-greene-thinks-all-americans-should-visit-cuba-now). Beyond the embargo, the [art scene](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-05-20/discovering-cuban-culture) in Cuba thrives—it's full of exciting and experimental work, and much of it is largely affordable. You can even bring artwork back with you to the States without much hassle. *—Liz Dosta*

items.title: Milford Sound, New Zealand
items.caption: Thirteen years and six films later, Peter Jackson’s re-imagining of Tolkien’s tomes is complete. (We think.) As the stand-in for Middle-earth, New Zealand may never be the same again—but now that filming is over, the hobbit-seeking hordes might go elsewhere. Now’s the time to plan a trip to the Milford Sound area in the South Island, outside adventure travel capital Queenstown. Go "tramping" (hiking) along mountain faces, through dense, electric green forests, and past waterfalls (the Routeburn Track is highly recommended)—many of these locations appeared in the *Lord of the Rings* films. (Milford Sound, for example, stood in for Fangorn Forest.) *—Laura Dannen Redman*

items.title: Guangzhou, China
items.caption: China Southern Airlines has launched direct flights between JFK and the trading port of Guangzhou—a blessing for business travelers. Plus, Guangzhou’s arts scene is growing almost as quickly as its economy. Check out the Rem Koolhaas–designed Times Museum, then fill up on dim sum in the buzzy Taojin Lu neighborhood. *—Alice Newell-Hanson*

featureContentItems.seoTitle: Top 15 Places to Go in 2015: Cuba, Helsinki, Cape Town
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Here are Condé Nast Traveler editors’ top 15 picks for where to go in 2015.

featureContentItems.hed: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.
featureContentItems.dek: The website [Sightsmap](http://www.sightsmap.com/) is a heat map for people who love travel and photography. It uses data from [Google Maps’ Panoramio photo uploader tool] (http://www.panoramio.com) to find out where travelers are taking the most pictures. Here’s what we learned about the most photographed spots in the United States—some of the findings may surprise you.

items.title: [10. Los Angeles, CA](http://www.sightsmap.com/los-angeles)
items.caption: Although Los Angeles may not be the most popular photo site with Panoramio users, there’s one place where it reigns supreme: Instagram. The photo-sharing service recently revealed its list of the [most ‘grammed spots of 2014] (http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-12-04/the-10-most-instagrammed-spots-of-2014), and several SoCal destinations—including Disneyland and Dodger Stadium—made the list. Meanwhile, the Panoramio list favors performing arts venues and sports stadiums, with the Staples Center, Ahmanson Theatre, and Dorothy Chandler Pavilion all getting high marks.

items.title: [9. Walt Disney World, FL](http://sightsmap.com/walt-disney-world)
items.caption: The [Walt Disney World](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-05-14/adult-disney-world-travel-guide-hotels-restaurants-activities) complex in Florida technically has its own town, Lake Buena Vista. People come from all over the world to visit the amusement park and resorts, and they take plenty of pictures while they’re there. Unsurprisingly, Cinderella's Castle (pictured) was the most popular spot in the Magic Kingdom. But many of the most photographed spots are in Epcot, including Norway (no. 4), Japan (no. 3), and the Mexico Pavilion (no. 9). And the iconic Epcot ball is #1.

items.title: [8. Key West, FL](http://sightsmap.com/key-west)
items.caption: As the southernmost point in the continental United States, Key West has drawn visitors as diverse as Ernest Hemingway and the cast of MTV's *The Real World.* Unsurprisingly, its most photographed spots include the Southernmost House, Hemingway’s former home (and its polydactyl cats), and other watery locales like the Shipwreck and Maritime Museums.

items.title: [7. Boston, MA](http://sightsmap.com/boston)
items.caption: Thanks to the Bay State’s key role in the founding of America, [Boston](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-12-12/what-not-to-do-in-boston) has plenty of historic attractions on offer. The city’s most photographed list is a mix of the classic and the modern, including skyscrapers like the John Hancock Tower alongside the Ether Monument (also known as the Good Samaritan), the Massachusetts State House, and the site of the Boston Massacre.

items.title: [6. Las Vegas Strip, NV](http://sightsmap.com/las-vegas-strip)
items.caption: While [Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-12-18/things-to-do-in-las-vegas-weekend-guide) is one of the most popular tourist spots in America, it’s only one part of Las Vegas that’s getting love on Panoramio: the Strip, which is where many tourists spend the majority of their visits. Unsurprisingly, that means that many of the most photographed spots are casinos, including Bally's, Caesar's Palace, and the Venetian. The most popular non-Strip spot in Sin City is "Vegas Vic," the famous neon cowboy.

items.title: [5. Washington, D.C.](http://sightsmap.com/washington-dc)
items.caption: As the nation’s capital, [Washington, D.C.](http://www.cntraveler.com/destinations/washington-dc) is heavy with history. And many of its most photographed spots are places named for some of our past leaders, including the Jefferson Memorial, the Lincoln Memorial, and the Washington Monument. But some other interesting spots make the cut, including Blair House (where many guests of the White House stay during their visit) and President’s Park (better known as the White House lawn).

items.title: [4. San Francisco, CA](http://sightsmap.com/san-francisco)
items.caption: San Francisco is the 20th best city in the world, [as voted by Condé Nast Traveler readers.] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/6). And while destinations like Coit Tower, the Golden Gate Bridge, Fisherman’s Wharf, and Alcatraz all appear on the most photographed list, the no. 1 photo tag is simply “San Francisco.” That’s right: the city itself is the star.

items.title: [3. Chicago, IL](http://sightsmap.com/chicago)
items.caption: *Condé Nast Traveler* readers love Chicago, putting it at no. 23 on our poll of the [top 25 cities in the world] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-20/top-25-cities-in-the-world-readers-choice-awards-2014/3). The Windy City is known for its skyline, so it’s no surprise that some of its most photographed spots are landmarks like the Ferris Wheel, the Willis Tower, the Bean, and—coming in at no. 1—the Art Institute of Chicago.

items.title: [2. Niagara Falls, NY](http://sightsmap.com/niagara-falls)
items.caption: Both the United States and Canada experienced a high volume of tourists who wanted to photograph [the gorgeous waterfalls](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-01-10/niagara-falls-frozen-ice) on both sides of the border. Here, it’s all about the vantage points: Hot spots include the Rainbow Bridge, the Observation Deck, and the Maid of the Mists boats that go through the falls.

items.title: [1. New York, NY](http://sightsmap.com/new-york-city)
items.caption: [New York City](http://www.cntraveler.com/destinations/new-york-city) is not only the most photographed city in the US, it’s the most photographed city in the entire world. Visitors to the Big Apple like to take pictures of the city’s architectural marvels, including the Empire State Building, the 9/11 Memorial, the Flatiron Building, and Grand Central Terminal. But the big winner was the [Guggenheim Museum](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/new-york/solomon-r-guggenheim-museum), whose circular shape and iconic works of art prove an irresistible combination.

featureContentItems.seoTitle: New York, Chicago, San Francisco: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Here’s what we learned about the most photographed spots in the United States—some of the findings may surprise you.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: The Most Photographed Places in the U.S.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Here’s what we learned about the most photographed spots in the United States—some of the findings may surprise you.

fields.caption:
The observation deck at One World Trade Center won't be open until spring 2015 at the earliest, but, when it does, it'll let visitors look out over New York City from approximately 1,250 feet above. Plans for restaurants, a multimedia gallery, and another ultra-fast elevator ride are also in the works.




 




**More on Incredible Views:**




[Amazing Observatories Around the World Perfect for Stargazing](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/amazing-observatories-you-can-visit_slideshow_item0_1)




[Room With a View](http://www.cntraveler.com/room-with-a-view/photos-room-with-a-view)




[Hotel Rooftops, Balconies and Terraces Worth the Price of the Room](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/best-hotel-rooftops-balconies-and-terraces)
fields.title: One World Observatory

fields.name: Lilit Marcus
fields.shortBio: Lilit Marcus is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor.
fields.bio: Lilit Marcus is a Brooklyn-based journalist and *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor. Her first book, *Save the Assistants: A Guide for Surviving and Thriving in the Workplace,* was published by Hyperion. Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

featureContentItems.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers pick their favorite destination spas in the world.

items.title: [Red Mountain Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/bermuda/red-mountain-resort-spa-st-george-st-george-utah)
items.caption:
Our readers rave about the location of this resort, calling it "heaven on Earth, close to national park day excursions." They also appreciated the activities: The resort offers daily guided hikes through nearby Snow Canyon State Park, fitness and health classes, and plenty of ways to be pampered at the spa. "Fabulous for all sorts of activities at any level," said one reader, "rest and relaxation by the pool or in a secluded hammock."







**Overall Score: 80.8**


See full rating information for **[Red Mountain Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/bermuda/red-mountain-resort-spa-st-george-st-george-utah)**.

items.title: [Canyon Ranch, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-tucson-tucson-arizona)
items.caption:
This is one of two Canyon Ranch resorts to make our readers' Top Ten list. One fan raved about the experience here, calling it "the ultimate in a vacation destination: diverse choices of activities, healthy, delicious, clean food, all the pampering one might desire, workshops on a variety of topics, and most importantly, a dedicated staff." Of course, all that comes with the beautiful backdrop of the Sonoran desert and the Santa Catalina Mountains. Said one happy guest: "No matter what state you arrive in, you'll leave feeling fantastic."




**Overall Score: 87.3**


See full rating information for **[Canyon Ranch, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-tucson-tucson-arizona)**.

items.title: [Canyon Ranch, Lenox](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-lenox-lenox-massachusetts)
items.caption:
This wellness resort in the Berkshires is "R&R for the soul," a reader raves. The architectural focal point is Bellefontaine Mansion, an 1897 Gilded Age house, modeled after the Petit Trianon in Versailles, that used to be a Jesuit seminary. Rooms are decorated in warm neutral tones and have Italian bed linens and granite and cherrywood bathrooms. Staff "set the bar high—and I mean high—for all spa- and wellness-focused vacations," according to another reader. The 100,000-square-foot spa has saunas, cold-dip pools, and inhalation rooms.




**Overall Score: 89.7**


See full rating information for **[Canyon Ranch, Lenox](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/canyon-ranch-lenox-lenox-massachusetts)**.

items.title: [Lodge at Woodloch](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/lodge-at-woodloch-hawley-hawley-pennsylvania)
items.caption: Ninety miles from New York City, this 2006 property with more than 150 wooded acres and a private lake in northeast Pennsylvania is “a quiet and serene resort, the perfect weekend getaway.” Excursions include fly-fishing and trail biking trips, though some prefer to stay on-site for a river stone massage at the spa. All guest rooms have private verandas and oversize marble bathrooms. Guests enter under a porte cochere into the plant-filled Garden Hall, which has a 14-foot glass cupola and a balcony looking onto the lake. Tree restaurant’s chef uses fresh, local ingredients, including those from the resort’s farm-to-table garden, to flavor dishes such as marinated lamb loin with mushroom risotto, haricots verts, and balsamic reduction. The 40,000-square-foot spa has 27 treatment rooms.

items.title: [Miraval, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/miraval-tucson-tucson-arizona)
items.caption:
Guests of this mind-body-spirit resort, near the Santa Catalina Mountains in the High Sonoran Desert, report having "life-changing, transformative stays." Villas have earth tones and are made from sustainable materials, while the grounds are "spectacular yet intimate." All meals, snacks, and non-alcoholic beverages are included and "are so inspired and flavorful, it’s hard to believe they’re so healthy." The spa’s fusion therapies combine massage, stretching, acupuncture, craniosacral therapy, and sound therapy. "Pampering, supportive staff are dedicated and love their jobs—and it shows."




**Overall Score: 92.8**


See full rating information for **[Miraval, Tucson](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/miraval-tucson-tucson-arizona)**.

items.title: [Mii Amo, Sedona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/mii-amo-sedona-sedona-united-states)
items.caption:
"The staff and facilities are phenomenal" at this "outstanding, outlandish spa retreat" connected to the Enchantment Resort in a red-rock canyon sacred to Native Americans. The "truly healing environment" incorporates design elements such as adobe brick, wood, and indigenous stone, and includes a Japanese-inspired lobby courtyard. Adobe casitas sit on the banks of a stream. Guests choose from three-, four- and seven-night programs, called Journeys, that include spa treatments by "super-experienced therapists" using custom-blended oils and lotions. Mii Amo Café’s health-conscious dishes are made with seasonal produce, and the Juice Bar serves energy drinks and smoothies. "The food is like no other spa food. I mean, it’s really good."




**Overall Score: 94.1**


See full rating information for **[Mii Amo, Sedona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/mii-amo-sedona-sedona-united-states)**.

items.title: [BodyHoliday at LeSport, St. Lucia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/st-lucia/bodyholiday-at-lesport-st-lucia-st-lucia-st-lucia)
items.caption:
The only Caribbean property on our Top Destination Spas list, BodyHoliday on St. Lucia combines the best of a destination spa with an island resort—few other destination spas are able to offer Scuba classes while there’s no pressure to participate in a strict agenda of classes. “With all the activities available you can choose to be a busy or lazy as you like.” Food at the four restaurants is healthy and fresh, but not spartan and unlike many destination spas, BodyHoliday serves alcohol. “The perfect place to wind down, relax, do sports, eat healthy, and just enjoy.”




**Overall Score: 94.1**


See full rating information for **[BodyHoliday at LeSport, St. Lucia](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/st-lucia/bodyholiday-at-lesport-st-lucia-st-lucia-st-lucia)**.

items.title: [Lake Austin Spa Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/lake-austin-spa-resort-austin-texas)
items.caption:
At this "amazingly secluded resort in the heart of Austin," guests can sit on their private porches overlooking either the gardens or lake (kayaks are available). After morning exercise classes, afternoon programs typically include seminars on topics like meditation and mastering your metabolism as well as cooking classes. The LakeHouse Spa staff, treatments, and facilities all received perfect scores, while many readers commented on the beauty of the landscaped grounds: "What an oasis!"

**Overall Score: **95.3
items.credit: Courtesy of Lake Austin Spa Resort

items.title: [Cal-A-Vie](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/cal-a-vie-health-spa-vista-california)
items.caption:
At this 32-room southern California resort, fitness gets a French touch, at least when it comes to the "Provencal-inspired décor and priceless antiques." A typical day at Cal-a-Vie begins with a morning hike through the canyons in the foothills above San Diego, followed by a breakfast of fresh fruits and whole grains, and then classes from ab workouts to zumba. For those so inclined, "injectables," including Botox and B12 are offered while Cal-a-Vie also has its own 18-hole golf course.




**Overall Score: 95.3**


See full rating information for **[Cal-a-Vie](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/cal-a-vie-health-spa-vista-california)**.

items.title: [Rancho La Puerta, Tecate](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/mexico/rancho-la-puerta-tecate-baja-mexico)
items.caption: **Our readers say**: “It’s a fabulous spa in a dream setting.” The 3,000-acre resort below Mount Kuchumaa, which is sacred to some Native Americans, has mountains, boulders, meadows, grasslands, woodlands, and chaparral on its grounds. The formal hiking program takes full advantage of the terrain; other options include watsu, acupuncture, hot river-stone massage, and craniosacral therapy. Built in Spanish colonial–style, red-brick casitas with tile roofs and outdoor patios are set amid extensive gardens. “This is one of my favorite places to rest, relax, and revitalize.” “Staff are helpful and friendly.” “Fantastic meals” are included in the rate—the locally sourced cuisine is primarily vegetarian. “It’s the best place to regain your health—physical and mental.” There’s a one-week

featureContentItems.seoDescription: Condé Nast Traveler readers pick their favorite destination spas in the world.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Condé Nast Traveler readers pick their favorite destination spas in the world.

fields.caption:
Our readers rave about the location of this resort, calling it "heaven on Earth, close to national park day excursions." They also appreciated the activities: The resort offers daily guided hikes through nearby Snow Canyon State Park, fitness and health classes, and plenty of ways to be pampered at the spa. "Fabulous for all sorts of activities at any level," said one reader, "rest and relaxation by the pool or in a secluded hammock."







**Overall Score: 80.8**


See full rating information for **[Red Mountain Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/caribbean/bermuda/red-mountain-resort-spa-st-george-st-george-utah)**.

featureContentItems.hed: Can Big Data Solve Travel’s Most Vexing Problem?
featureContentItems.dek: A startup called FLYR aims to predict with near certainty whether airfares will go up or down. It's an idea that's been tried before—but could the future of fare-watching finally be now?
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Can Big Data Solve Travel’s Most Vexing Problem?
featureContentItems.seoDescription: A new website called FLYR aims to predict with near certainly whether airfares will go up or down. It's an idea that's been tried before—but could the future of fare-watching finally be now?
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Can Big Data Solve Travel’s Most Vexing Problem?
featureContentItems.socialDescription: A new website called FLYR aims to predict with near certainly whether airfares will go up or down. It's an idea that's been tried before—but could the future of fare-watching finally be now?
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d3fae6d14554241344fae8]||||||





FLYR recently launched [a fare prediction tool](http://beta.getflyr.com/#/) that gives users advice on whether to buy a ticket now or wait for a better price. Unlike the many airfare forecasters that have come before, FLYR says its predictions are based on data specific to the flight in question—not just on average fares for a particular route and day.

That novel approach gives the service an accuracy rate of more than 80 percent, according to FLYR senior content strategist Andrew Jing. To make its predictions, FLYR’s algorithm considers previous airfare patterns and "historical trends from millions of unique cases," he says. While Jing declined to say how FLYR obtains that data, he did say that "we are constantly running backtests on all of our predictions,” to improve the site's functionality.

Here's how it works: After searching FLYR for a particular departure, travelers can select a "Predictions" button to see the 24-hour fare forecast, along with the probability of a future fare change or flight sell-out. By selecting a "FareBeacon" button, users can opt in to email notifications that track specific flights. FLYR directs users to partner sites for the actual booking of seats.

At present, FLYR tracks more than 1,900 domestic routes—though information on Southwest and many American Airlines flights is not available—and it looks as far as 120 days in advance. The start-up plans on adding select European flights in April with other international routes coming mid-year. Also coming soon is FareKeep, a pay service that will let "users to lock in a price prior to actually purchasing the fare outright,” Jing says.

But FLYR isn't alone in its quest to use flight-level data to inform airfare predictions. [A recently released iOS app from Hopper](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-01-28/morning-news-a-new-app-from-hopper-promises-to-predict-the-future-of-airfares) makes its own calls about future prices, and it provides guidance on the best travel dates and alternate airports that may have cheaper flights. Hopper says *its* accuracy rate is 95 percent. An Android version is planned, and Hopper is adding some of the app's predictive features to [its website](http://www.hopper.com/).

More airfare data—and more competition to parse that data—should help consumers make more informed choices in the long run. But with more and more forecasters becoming available, it may soon be hard to figure out which one to use. Until a dominant forecaster—or a service that aggregates predictions from multiple forecasters—is available, travelers are left where they started, checking multiple sites before booking to find the best price. Some things, unlike airfares, never change.

fields.name: Zach Everson
fields.shortBio: Zach Everson is a Washington, D.C.-based freelance writer, focusing on travel and food.
fields.bio:
Zach Everson is a Washington, D.C.-based freelance writer, focusing on travel and food. He has contributed to *The Wall Street Journal*, Air Canada's *enRoute*, *USA Today* and Eater. When traveling he's usually looking for Caravaggios, bourbon-based cocktails, and restaurants with
cheese carts.

featureContentItems.hed: American Airlines Introduces Retro-Themed Amenities Kits
featureContentItems.dek: Good news for aviation geeks, nostalgic travelers, and design aficionados: Starting this month, you won't need to scour eBay and thrift shops to find a TWA or America West memorabilia, thanks to American Airlines' brand-new amenities kits.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d3ef10d14554241344f6d3]||||||





Available on most international and transcontinental flights, these limited-edition collectibles pay tribute to the eight carriers that American Airlines has gobbled up, as well as the airline's own old logo ( [which many fliers were sad to lose](http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/new-american-airlines-logo-triggers-ire-and-sense-d-j-vu-146659)).

Aside from being deliciously vintage, these heritage kits sum up how far American Airlines has come from being a [consolidation of scrappy regional carriers](http://www.aa.com/i18n/amrcorp/corporateInformation/facts/history.jsp) to the world's largest airline. Here's a nostalgic look back some of these gone-but-not-forgotten airlines.






__AirCal__

Though American Airlines took over the regional carrier based in Orange County in [1987](http://articles.latimes.com/1987-07-02/business/fi-1823_1_american-airlines), you can now grab this sun-colored piece of nostalgia almost thirty years later. Its fare from SoCal to San Francisco, by the way, was [under $15 in 1967](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_California). Good luck finding airport parking for that now.






__US Airways__

It feels a bit strange to eulogize an airline whose livery can still be seen, including on its own [branded credit cards that are still being issued](http://www.worldgotbigger.com/). Still, US Airways, once called Allegheny Airlines and USAir, exemplifies how airlines are constantly reincarnated under different brands.


[#image: /photos/54d3eec4f743358e0c1de186]||||||





__TWA__

One of the greats in aviation history, St. Louis-based Trans World Airlines once served varied routes reaching Tanzania, Bahrain, and other far-flung destinations. The brand's adventurous spirit lives on through the [handsome, still-futuristic JFK terminal](http://gothamist.com/2014/10/14/ohny_twa_terminal.php#photo-1) that was designed by Eero Saarinen.

__America West__

Like many second (or third or fourth) marriages, US Airways is bringing its own set of stepchildren to its union with American. Arizona-based America West took over US Airways in 2005 and opted to forgo its own branding. Now with American Airlines initiative, you can have an amenities kit bearing America West's unique, landscape-inspired logo.

fields.name: Chaney Kwak
fields.shortBio: Chaney Kwak travels, eats, and writes.
fields.bio: In addition to Condé Nast Traveler, Chaney Kwak's writing appears in The Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Departures, Virtuoso Life, and National Geographic books. He is a co-author of the 2014 Fodor's Guide to Berlin.

featureContentItems.hed: News Flash: The Weather Is Not Your Airline’s Responsibility
featureContentItems.dek: Recent storms have led *Condé Nast Traveler*'s Ombudsman to issue a reminder: If your flight is delayed due to the weather, try to be flexible and remain calm. Remember, the airline didn’t cause the problem.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d3e4e0d14554241344f4cb]|||
Air passenger waits out winter storm delay at Logan International Airport in Boston Massachusetts
|||





With the winter storms that keep coming and disrupting flights, I want to offer a reminder: [As we’ve previously discussed](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-11-21/holiday-travel-what-to-do-flight-delayed-canceled), airlines don’t guarantee their schedules. When weather, or anything else out of an airline’s control, causes a delay or cancellation, for the most part its only obligation is to get you to your final destination at its earliest opportunity on its own planes. It may take other steps, but that would be as a courtesy and not a requirement.

While trying to regroup and reschedule, you might become frustrated and tired, perhaps even livid if your airline is unhelpful and uncommunicative. I understand. I’ve had to [put myself on pause](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-01-02/the-ombudsmans-travel-new-years-resolution-count-to-five) in the past. If your flights were disrupted in the last few weeks, I hope your airline did its best to inform and reschedule you. My other hope is that you were able to be reasonable throughout the tumult. Remember, gate agents and flight crews do not cause the delays. Treat them with respect and you’ll be more likely to get the same in return. Besides, even if the agents aren’t handling the disruption well, yelling and demanding is not likely to help you get on a plane any sooner. These [tips from Brett Snyder](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-01-09/stranded-at-the-airport-tips?), on the other hand, could help your cause.

Let’s talk about why airlines don’t owe you anything if there’s a weather delay. First, strictly from a rational perspective, airlines can’t control the weather or the dictates of air traffic control. When they can’t fly their planes, it throws their system out of whack and costs them money. Would it really make sense for them to provide hotel rooms, give food vouchers, and offer compensation every time a plane is delayed or cancelled due to the weather? I imagine ticket prices would go up considerably.

Then there’s the reality of their contracts of carriage. As an example, let’s look at an excerpt of [Virgin America’s](https://www.virginamerica.com/cms/dam/vx-pdf/contract-of-carriage.pdf). Why Virgin America? Because it is consistently rated as one of the best domestic airlines, but you’ll see that even it will not reimburse you for consequential expenses, nor is it obligated to offer compensation for reasons outside its control:

*“__Schedules and Operations:__ Virgin America will endeavor to carry Guests and their baggage with reasonable dispatch; however, times shown in timetables, advertisements, or elsewhere are not guaranteed and form no part of this Contract of Carriage. … Schedules are subject to change without notice. Virgin America is not responsible for or liable for failure to make connections, or to operate any flight according to schedule… Under no circumstances shall Virgin America be liable for any indirect, consequential, incidental, punitive or special damages including, without limitation, damages for lost revenue or profits, loss of use, lost wages, or business interruption arising from the foregoing."* 

*“Force Majeure: In the event of any Force Majeure event, Virgin America may, without notice, cancel, terminate, divert, postpone or delay any flight or the right of carriage or reservation of traffic accommodations without liability except to issue an involuntary refund. …”* 

That seems clear enough. Let me clarify something else. This is not an apologia for the airlines. Sometimes they don’t deliver compensation even [when it’s due](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-13/quick-fix-getting-bumped-from-a-flight), or they are astoundingly opaque when all you want is a simple answer. I also don’t want to demonize them— there are times when they do everything they can to help. I offer this information because I want you to avoid unnecessary frustration. We receive many letters from readers regarding delays and cancellations. Unless you’re convinced the airline could have avoided the flight irregularity and you have evidence to back it up, don’t expect to receive compensation or much sympathy. Better to use the time and energy to plan your next trip, rather than write to the airline in what is most likely a futile attempt to gain satisfaction.

*Have a travel question you want answered? Email ombudsman@cntraveler.com, or tweet us @CNTraveler #dearombudsman.*
featureContentItems.seoTitle: News Flash: The Weather Is Not Your Airline’s Responsibility
featureContentItems.seoDescription: A reminder from Condé Nast Traveler's Ombudsman: If your flight is delayed due to the weather, try to be flexible and remain calm—remember, the airline didn’t cause the problem.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: News Flash: The Weather Is Not Your Airline’s Responsibility

fields.name: Eric Jordan
fields.shortBio: If there’s one thing Eric knows after 12 years as *Traveler*’s Ombudsman, it’s to be ready for anything.
fields.bio: Eric is also an actor and screenwriter, which has limited his ability to travel as much as he would like. He has still managed to visit 48 states (Alaska and Kentucky, he’s coming), France, Italy (for dinner), the UK, Canada, Mexico, The Bahamas, Australia, and New Zealand, so far his favorite destination. Along with the temperate climate, the big mountains and the vividly blue waters, it’s probably because New Zealand is tied with Denmark as the least corrupt nation in the world, something he appreciates after 12 years as mediator on the Ombudsman column. During that time, Eric has read thousands of letters from readers who encountered problems on land, sea, and in the sky. He’s learned that no matter how well you plan, you always need to be ready to improvise. He thinks there’s nothing better than an unplanned day in an unexplored place, particularly if it involves time in the water or on the snow.
